_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Tanks are ISO (International Organization for Standardization)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION
Boasso Newark Terminal LLC (Boasso Global) operates a transportation terminal located at 80 Doremus Ave in Newark, NJ which currently consists of Intermodal Tank Containers (ISOs) transportation operations. The transportation terminal provides temporary transportation storage and maintenance for ISO containers incidental to transportation to the final destination selected by the shipper.  ISOs are manufactured according to specifications from the International Organization of Standardization (ISO) and are suitable for multiple transport methods such as truck, rail, or ship.  In-transit storage services are provided to a wide variety of clients and industries and the specific chemicals and inventory quantities onsite can vary. Temporary storage at the facility includes ISOs containing chemicals listed as Extraordinarily Hazardous Substances (EHS) as defined in New Jerseys Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (TCPA) at, N.J.A.C. 7:31 (which incorporates, by reference, the federal Chemical Accident Prevention rules at 40 CFR 68).  Onsite quantities of EHS may exceed applicable regulatory thresholds and, as such, the facility is subject to the requirements of TCPA.  To comply with TCPA, Boasso Global is required to prepare and implement a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to prevent and/or minimize the consequences of a catastrophic release or explosion.  A Program Level 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) is being resubmitted as part of the 5-year update in accordance with 40 CFR § 68.190(b) with changes specified at N.J.A.C. 7:31-7.1(c)1 and 2.

1.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Accidental release prevention is inherent within the design of the ISOs. EHS products must be handled appropriately to reduce potential exposure hazards to employees, visitors, and nearby members of the community.  Safe operation is enhanced by the careful manner of handling EHS products, storage of ISOs containing EHS in the restricted area of the secondary containm

ent, and effective training of employees.
Furthermore, the facilitys Emergency Response Plan is designed to minimize potential hazards to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous material or hazardous material constituents to air, soil, or surface water.  It also is company policy to comply with Federal and State rules and regulations.  
Evaluation of the threshold quantity includes substances in a "covered process", defined as use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or onsite movement operations that have an EHS present.  Facilities are subject to the requirements of TCPA if the total quantity of EHS in covered processes exceed the threshold limits specified in N.J.A.C. 7:31-6.  Storage of ISO containers holding EHS constitutes a covered process as defined by TCPA.  

2.	The Facility and Regulated Substances Handled
The covered process is limited to movement and storage of closed ISO containers.  EHS are not removed from their containers or transferred, heated, processed, or used in any other way at the facility.
The Boasso Newark Terminal handles and stores ISOs with maximum volume of 6,500 imperial gallons that are typically constructed from stainless steel and housed in steel framework to both allow for stacking and to protect the tank during shipping.  Twenty-foot (20) long ISOs are brought to the facility on trailer chassis by over-the-road trucks.  ISOs may be empty and clean, empty (but sometimes containing de minimis amounts of chemicals that cannot be pumped out of the container during delivery), or full or almost full of EHS chemicals.  Boassos RMP covers EHS-containing ISOs that are full or almost full. ISOs are unloaded from the chassis by container handlers and are moved to an available temporary storage location onsite, also known as the restricted area of the secondary containment, by the container handler or by a yard truck and trailer chassis.  Empty ISOs may be stacked up

to three high and full ISOs may be stacked up to two high. Stacks may be several rows deep. While in storage, ISOs maybe moved for access to other ISOs below or behind.  ISOs ready for shipment are loaded to trailer chassis by a container handler. 

The following toxic EHS have been identified as potentially stored temporarily at the terminal at any given time:
?	Trimethylchlorosilane (CAS # 75-77-4) 
?	Ethylenediamine (CAS # 107-15-3) 
?	Vinyl Acetate Monomer (CAS # 108-05-4) 
The following flammable EHS have been identified as potentially stored temporarily at the terminal at any given time:
?	Difluoroethane (CAS # 75-37-6)
?	Dimethyl Ether (CAS # 115-10-6)
?	Ethyl Ether (CAS# 60-29-7)
?	Isopentane (CAS # 78-78-4)
?	Isoprene (CAS # 78-79-5) 

3.	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 
The following engineering and administrative controls and safeguards for the EHS handling process are in place to prevent release:
?	Mechanical controls (Heavy-duty container handler used for ISOs containing material; ISOs include a frame to protect the tank; Light-duty container handler is equipped with scale to prevent lifting of heavy ISOs; ISOs equipped with pressure safety valves to prevent over-pressurization).
?	Administrative/human factor controls (ISOs remain sealed while onsite; ISOs are inspected when they arrive onsite to identify potential wear, corrosion, or other potential leak points; Container handler operators are trained in proper operation; Yard is inspected daily).
?	Housekeeping/maintenance controls (Container handlers are routinely inspected for proper operation; Yard is kept free of debris).
?	Boasso Global operators involved with the handling of ISOs have been trained to inspect ISOs arriving onsite to mitigate the potential for leaks, and to identify leaks during temporary storage.  Boasso Global operators do not respond to leak or spill events and are instructed to notify their emergency response contra

ctor (Skytank) and 911 immediately in the event of an EHS release.

4.	Five-year Accident History 
In the last five-years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5.	The Emergency Response Plan
This facility's Emergency Response Plan includes response actions for site personnel for multiple types of emergencies.  The primary elements of the plan include emergency reporting and evacuation procedures, emergency personnel responsibilities, command of responses, training, and site-specific details such as emergency contacts and maps with pertinent locations illustrated on the facility map within the Emergency Response Plan for the Newark Terminal.  The facility is a non-responding source, meaning it relies on local emergency responders in the event of an accidental release. A copy of this plan has been provided to the Newark City Fire Department and the Newark Police Department Local Emergency Planning Committee.  

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
The final design and construction of secondary containment was completed on September 15, 2022, and the RMP has been modified to include this.
